unnormalised: The summer of '98 was relentlessly hot in Delhi, the kind that made even the pigeons seek refuge under the meager shade of the neem trees. I was 16, preparing for my IIT entrance exams, and trigonometry was my nemesis. I remember sitting in my cramped room, the ceiling fan whirring uselessly, a copy of S.L. Loney's trigonometry textbook open in front of me. The problems swam before my eyes: "Prove that sin(A + B) = sinA cosB + cosA sinB." It felt like an alien language.
normalised: The summer of ninety eight was relentlessly hot in Delhi, the kind that made even the pigeons seek refuge under the meager shade of the neem trees. I was sixteen, preparing for my I-I-T entrance exams, and trigonometry was my nemesis. I remember sitting in my cramped room, the ceiling fan whirring uselessly, a copy of S.L. Loney's trigonometry textbook open in front of me. The problems swam before my eyes: "Prove that sine of A plus B equals sine A cosine B plus cosine A sine B." It felt like an alien language.

unnormalised: My father, a retired maths teacher, noticed my struggle. He’d always been a practical man, finding applications for abstract concepts in the everyday world. One sweltering afternoon, he called me outside. “Come, beta,” he said, “let’s understand this trigonometry with something real.”
normalised: My father, a retired maths teacher, noticed my struggle. He’d always been a practical man, finding applications for abstract concepts in the everyday world. One sweltering afternoon, he called me outside. “Come, beta,” he said, “let’s understand this trigonometry with something real.”

unnormalised: He pointed to the charpoy in our courtyard. “Look at the legs of this charpoy. They form an angle with the ground. If the charpoy is 6 ft long and the leg is 2 ft high, what is the angle? We can use tan theta = opposite/adjacent.” I stared blankly. He sighed. "Use Pythagoras theorem to calculate the base."
normalised: He pointed to the charpoy in our courtyard. “Look at the legs of this charpoy. They form an angle with the ground. If the charpoy is six feet long and the leg is two feet high, what is the angle? We can use tan theta equals opposite divided by adjacent.” I stared blankly. He sighed. "Use Pythagoras theorem to calculate the base."

unnormalised: He then proceeded to explain how the angles changed as one of us sat on it. "See, the height is decreasing. Calculate the new tan theta. What's the new angle?" That's when I started to understand.
normalised: He then proceeded to explain how the angles changed as one of us sat on it. "See, the height is decreasing. Calculate the new tan theta. What's the new angle?" That's when I started to understand.

unnormalised: The next day, he took me to Qutub Minar. "See that tall structure? Imagine a right-angled triangle. We can't measure the height directly, but we can measure the angle of elevation and the distance from the base. Using tan theta, we can calculate the height." He estimated the distance to be ~72 meters. We used a rudimentary clinometer he’d fashioned from a protractor and a straw to measure the angle of elevation – it was about 68 degrees. Plugging the values into tan(68 degrees) = height/72 m, we got a surprisingly accurate estimate of Qutub Minar's height. (The actual height is 73 m, a close match given our basic tools!)

He estimated the distance to be approximately seventy two meters. We used a rudimentary clinometer he’d fashioned from a protractor and a straw to measure the angle of elevation – it was about sixty eight degrees. Plugging the values into tan of sixty eight degrees equals height divided by seventy two meters, we got a surprisingly accurate estimate of Qutub Minar's height. (The actual height is seventy three meters, a close match given our basic tools!)

unnormalised: Even a simple kite flying scenario turned into a lesson. "If you fly a kite with 100 m of string and the angle of elevation is 30 degrees, how high is the kite?" He illustrated it with a quick sketch on a scrap of paper, showing me how sin 30 degrees = height/100m.
normalised: Even a simple kite flying scenario turned into a lesson. "If you fly a kite with one hundred meters of string and the angle of elevation is thirty degrees, how high is the kite?" He illustrated it with a quick sketch on a scrap of paper, showing me how sine thirty degrees equals height divided by one hundred meters.

unnormalised: He continued with the sundial in Jantar Mantar, demonstrating how its shadow and the angle of the sun are related to the time of day using trigonometric functions and spherical geometry, which was much more advanced than what I was learning, but he explained in simple terms. He showed me old tables listing declination values for different days of the year to calculate the Equation of Time.

unnormalised: From then on, trigonometry wasn't just a collection of formulas in a book. It was the angle of the sun, the height of the Qutub Minar, the tilt of the charpoy. It was real. My scores improved, but more importantly, I started to see the beauty of maths in everything around me. I managed to get a seat at IIT Delhi, scoring 98% in Maths. And every time I see a triangle, or measure an angle, I remember that sweltering summer and the practical lessons that made all the difference. My father always said, geometry is the poetry of space.
